title: `spack module loads` behaviour and default package specification
body:
(I think that)  `spack module loads` command show too much modules.  

[Documentation link for `spack module loads`](https://spack.readthedocs.io/en/v0.10.0/module_file_support.html?highlight=module%20loads#spack-module-loads)

### Basic example:

```bash
$ spack install cmake
$ spack install cmake -ncurses

$ spack module loads cmake
# cmake@3.11.4%gcc@5.4.0~doc~ncurses+openssl+ownlibs~qt arch=linux-ubuntu16.04-x86_64 
module load cmake-3.11.4-gcc-5.4.0-wwzmxze
# cmake@3.11.4%gcc@5.4.0~doc+ncurses+openssl+ownlibs~qt arch=linux-ubuntu16.04-x86_64 
module load cmake-3.11.4-gcc-5.4.0-dtsol6q
```

### Expectation:

```bash
$ spack install cmake
$ spack install cmake -ncurses

$ spack module loads cmake
# cmake@3.11.4%gcc@5.4.0~doc+ncurses+openssl+ownlibs~qt arch=linux-ubuntu16.04-x86_64 
module load cmake-3.11.4-gcc-5.4.0-dtsol6q
```

As default variant for `cmake` package is `+ncurses`, as a user, I expect to do not care about it.
So when I write `spack module loads cmake`, I expect to show module coresponding to the befault behaviours, and not all cmake related module.

If you are not agree with it, why do you think actual behaviour is better / needed ?

### More information:
```
gitlab@250d64a2a414:~$ uname -a
Linux 250d64a2a414 3.13.0-43-generic #72-Ubuntu SMP Mon Dec 8 19:35:06 UTC 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
gitlab@250d64a2a414:~$ spack --version
0.11.2
gitlab@250d64a2a414:~$ spack arch 
linux-ubuntu16.04-x86_64
```

### Related question

I did not find a way to load every dependencies module for a particular package.
I am aware of `--dependencies`, or `-r` option, but I search for `--dependencies-only`.

As a workaround I use `head -n -2 `.
To keep my example, for now I use:
```
$ spack module loads -r cmake | head -n -2
```
Or the full command:
```
source <(spack module loads -r cmake | head -n -2)
```

### More context
I use spack to develop our own software.
So we load every dependencies with spack.
We have a package for our software but o develop we use:
```bash
# this command only on time
spack setup mysoft@master

# this command for every bash we need to compile/execute
source <(spack module loads -r mysoft@master | head -n -2)

cd build && cmake ..
```
